author: potuz
content: Hi, a bit off topic but I couldn't find a better place to ask. I'm thinking on writing an informal essay on cultural shock and need some help. Can you give me a reference for the usage of the term "linear combination" in the context of elliptic curves? I can even settle for "scalar multiplication" in this context. An old or original reference would be great, but otherwise some big renowned person using this terminology would be good too. I know Vitalik uses it, but I'm looking for some pure mathematician and specifically not from the cryptography environment.

author: bridge-bot
content: <dankrad> most pure mathematicians would call it an "exponentiation" rather than a "multiplication" because they are used to a different notation for groups/elliptic curves (this is just a matter of definition, rather than one or the other being correct)

author: kevaundray
content:
As dankrad mentioned, linear combination is another way to say multi-scalar multiplication or multi-exponentiation. Depending on whether you define your group using additive or multiplicative notation. 

If you want to look for references for the term "linear combination" and "elliptic curves" , there are some papers whom use the terminology "vectors" and "matrices" when referring to a set of group elements. You can see usage of this in section 1.1 of this paper <https://eprint.iacr.org/2019/944.pdf>

Section 2/2.1 also describes the dlog in terms of vector terminology, though this may be out of scope for the informal essay.

author: kevaundray
content:
Another reference is Bootle's thesis on the _Ideal Linear Commitment Model_ where the prover and verifier send vectors in this ideal model, which is then instantiated using groups.

<https://discovery.ucl.ac.uk/id/eprint/10079416/1/Bootle_000_Thesis.pdf> Skimming that paper or grepping for "linear combinations" should yield a ton of results concerning linear combination of group elements
